Graphical abstract In this paper, we successfully prepared magnetic SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 microspheres with uniform morphology and mesoporous MnO2 shell. The prepared material was used as a catalyst support for fabricating the Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst which exhibited excellent catalytic activity and easy recyclability in the environmental catalysis. In this study, magnetic SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 microspheres with uniform morphology and mesoporous MnO2 shell were successfully prepared. The MnO2 sheets structured mesoporous shell could provide a large specific surface area, thereby increasing the catalytically active sites. Thus, magnetic SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 microspheres were used as a catalyst support. Palladium nanoparticles (Pd NPs) were successfully anchored with high dispersion on SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 surface, successfully obtained Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst with a Pd weight percentage of 6%. The obtained nanocatalyst was employed in the hydrodechlorination of highly toxic 2,4-dichlorophenol and catalytic reduction of the widely used nitroaromatics and organic dyes under ambient conditions. In these catalytic reactions, the Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst with large and accessible pore surface area exhibited excellent catalytic activity as compared to other noble metal supported catalysts. The Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst could also be easily and conveniently recovered from the reaction mixture by using an external magnet, attributed to its magnetism, thus preventing the catalyst loss. Moreover, it could also be reused for at least six times without significant decrease in the catalytic activity, indicating its excellent reusability and stability. This study provides a useful platform and a new perspective for fabricating mesoporous MnO2 microspheres based noble metals modified catalysts for environmental catalysis. Keywords Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst Hydrodechlorination 2,4-Dichlorophenol Reduction Organic dyes 1 Introduction Over the last decades, with the continuous development of the chemical industry, significantly large amounts of organic hazardous substances have been discharged into the environment. One class of the organic hazardous substances includes the chlorophenols (CPs) [1–4], which are widely used in the synthesis of herbicides, dyes, and pesticides and as preservative agents for wood, paints, fibers, and leather. However, they have been identified as priority pollutants because of their acute toxicity, resistance to biodegradability, and strong bioaccumulation potential. Another type of hazardous organic pollutants includes the extensively used nitroaromatic compounds such as 4-nitrophenol (4-NP) and 2-nitroaniline (2-NA), which are also highly toxic compounds with potential carcinogenic and mutagenic effects [5–7]. The third class recognized pollutant includes the organic dyes (eg. Rhodamine B (RhB), methylene blue (MB), and methyl orange (MO)), although they are widely exploited in paper, textile, paints, printing, and plastics industries, their high toxicity and carcinogenic and mutagenic nature should not be ignored [8–10]. Therefore, with increasing consciousness for environment protection, proper disposal of the above mentioned organic hazardous pollutants becomes extremely necessary. Till date, several methods such as chemical oxidation, adsorption, flocculation, catalytic degradation, and electrooxidation have been developed to dispose these organic hazardous pollutants [11–16]. Among them, the catalytic degradation method is considered as the most effective, simple, and safe technique. Moreover, the catalytic method can lead to the effective conversion of the highly toxic organic compounds into harmless or significantly less toxic reaction byproducts [17,18]. Furthermore, these byproducts can always be efficiently utilized as potential candidates in several industrial applications. Therefore, design and fabrication of efficient catalysts for the catalytic conversion of highly toxic organic compounds into harmless and useful products is highly required. Noble metal nanoparticles (NMNPs) based catalysts have been proved to be the most efficient catalysts for the organic molecule catalytic transformation [19]. However, attributed to the van der Waals forces and their high surface energy, the naked NMNPs are apt to irreversible aggregation in solution during the preparation and the catalytic process, which subsequently reduces the catalytic activity [20]. To overcome the above mentioned shortcomings, functional catalyst supports have attracted tremendous and increasing interest, thus paving the way for the fabrication of NMNPs supported catalysts. According to the recent literatures, several types of functional materials including mesoporous carbon [21,22], graphene oxide [23], mesoporous silica (SiO2) [24], and metal–organic frameworks have been employed for the fabrication of NMNPs based catalysts [25–27]. In general, palladium (Pd) catalysts are initially synthesized as heterogeneous catalysts followed by loading onto active carbon, metal oxides, zeolites, polymers, or clay [28–34]. However, these catalysts still suffer from drawbacks such as comparatively complicated separation recycling process such as filtration and centrifugation. Therefore, fabrication of functional catalyst supports which exhibit easy recyclability, large surface area, tunable mesoporous structure, and high activity and stability is extremely meaningful for the preparation of NMNPs based catalysts. In these regards, mesoporous materials with magnetic component have attracted significant attention as promising candidates for catalysts supports [35–37]. In these years, magnetic catalysts have been reported to have the incomparable advantages over the traditional catalysts because of their high activity, magnetic recyclability, and reusability [38–42]. The magnetic mesoporous carbon and core–shell magnetic mesoporous SiO2 have already been reported as catalysts supports for fabrication of recyclable catalysts [43–46]. However, the widely used, cost-effective transition metal oxides, for example manganese dioxide (MnO2) and cerium(IV) oxide (CeO2) have rarely been used for the fabrication of magnetic mesoporous transition metal oxides microsphere, probably due to the capability of these transition metal oxides always generate separate NPs, attributed to their high reactivity and low-solubility-product constants of the transition metal hydroxide. Thus, it is imperative to prepare magnetic mesoporous transition metal oxides microspheres with a mesoporous or hierarchical transition metal oxides shell and a magnetic core for the fabrication of supported catalysts exhibiting magnetic recyclable properties. Based on the above mentioned considerations, herein we used the SiO2 NPs as the core, ferrocene was employed as the precursor to fabricate the SiO2@Fe3O4@C magnetic NPs, and then potassium permanganate (KMnO4) was introduced to react with the surface carbon layers to form the mesoporous MnO2 shell on the SiO2@Fe3O4 NPs, thus the novel magnetic SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 catalyst support was successfully obtained. Finally, the Pd NPs were anchored on the mesoporous MnO2 shell with high dispersion by impregnation-reduction method, which resulted in the formation of the Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst with a Pd weight percentage of 6%. The prepared nanocatalyst was empolyed for the environmental catalysis, hydrodechlorination (HDC) of highly toxic CPs, and catalytic reduction of the extensively used nitroaromatics and organic dyes under ambient conditions. The Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst exhibited excellent catalytic activities compared to other reported NMNPs based catalysts, attributed to the mesoporous structure of the MnO2 shell and highly dispersed Pd NPs that led to the enhancement in the accessibility of the active sites and the mass transfer effect. Moreover, the Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst could be easily recovered and reused without any decrease in the catalytic activity and stability. This study may promote the research of fabricating magnetic mesoporous transition metal oxides microsphere support based catalysts for environmental catalysis. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents Ferrocene, KMnO4, and tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS), used for the fabrication of SiO2@Fe3O4@C and SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2, were purchased from Aladdin Reagents. CPs, 4-NP, 2-NA, RhB, MB, MO and other nitroaromatics used in the catalytic studies were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (China). Other reagents and solvents were of analytical grade and used without further purification. Deionized H2O was used for all the experiments. 2.2 Preparation of SiO2@Fe3O4@C SiO2 NPs were synthesized by a modified Stöber protocol [47]. The SiO2@Fe3O4@C microspheres were prepared by a modified hydrothermal process [48]. Briefly, SiO2 NPs (100mg) and ferrocene (200mg) were dissolved in acetone (65mL) by ultrasonication for 30min to form monodisperse system. Next, H2O2 (2mL) was added dropwise into the mixture by a syringe and the contents were magnetically stirred for 1h, which resulted in the formation of a homogeneous suspension. Subsequently, this suspension was transferred to a Teflon autoclave and heated to 200°C, and the temperature was maintained constant for 40h. Further, the autoclave was cooled down to room temperature. The as-obtained products were washed with H2O and acetone solution three times, respectively, and dried overnight at 40°C in a vacuum oven. 2.3 Preparation of SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 Mesoporous MnO2 layers were formed on SiO2@Fe3O4@C spheres by the redox reaction between KMnO4 and carbon layers. Briefly, SiO2@Fe3O4@C spheres (200mg) and KMnO4 (140mg) were added into H2O (70mL) by ultrasonication for 30min and magnetic stirring for 10min. Subsequently, the mixture was transferred to a Teflon autoclave and heated to 160°C, and the temperature was maintained constant for 12h. After cooling down to room temperature, the product was washed with deionized H2O and ethanol three times, respectively, and dried overnight at 40°C in a vacuum oven. 2.4 Preparation of Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst Palladium acetate solution (1.2mL, 10mgmL−1) was added dropwise into deionized H2O (25mL). Subsequently, SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 (94mg) was added to the above mentioned solution and ultrasonically dispersed for 30min and then magnetically stirred for 5h. The dispersion was cooled down to 0°C, and excess sodium borohydride (NaBH4) solution was added dropwise. The solution was stirred for 12h and the resulting Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst was collected by using an external magnet, thoroughly washed with ethanol and deionized H2O, and finally dried overnight at 40°C in a vacuum oven. 2.5 General procedure for the catalytic HDC of 2,4-DCP HDC of 2,4-DCP was performed under ambient conditions. Briefly, Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst (10mg), 2,4-DCP (165mg, 1mmol), and NaOH (80mg, 2mmol) were added in distilled H2O (10mL) and ultrasonically dispersed for 3min. The two-neck flask (25mL) was connected with a H2 balloon. The HDC reaction conversion and selectivity were analyzed by gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS, Agilent 5977E). The used Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst was separated from the reaction mixture by using an external magnetic field, washed with ethanol, and dried overnight at 40°C in a vacuum oven for the next catalytic reaction. Moreover, the catalytic reaction was repeated six times. 2.6 Catalytic reduction of nitroaromatic compounds (4-NP and 2-NA) 4-NP (30μL, 0.01M) or 2-NA (60μL, 0.01M) was added to deionized H2O (2.7mL) in a Cuvette. Later, freshly prepared aqueous solution of NaBH4 (300μL, 0.1M) was added. After the addition of Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst (5μL, 5mgmL−1, ultrasonically dispersed), the reduction reaction started and the ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) spectroscopy was employed for monitoring the progress of the reduction reactions. 2.7 Catalytic reduction of organic dyes (RhB, MB, and MO) The procedure for the catalytic reduction of organic dyes by Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst was similar to that of the 4-NP or 2-NA. The concentrations of the dyes RhB, MB, and MO solutions are all 0.01M. While the volumes of the RhB, MB, and MO solutions used were 10, 20, and 30μL, respectively. 2.8 Characterization The morphology of the SiO2 NPs, SiO2@Fe3O4@C, and Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst was observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JSM-6701F) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Tecnai G2 F30). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the samples were evaluated using a Rigaku D/max-2400 diffractometer in the 2θ range of 20–80° using Cu-Kα radiation as the X-ray source. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Perkin-Elmer PHI-5702) was used to analyze the electronic states on the surface of the Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst. The surface area, pore volume, and pore size distribution of the samples were evaluated at 77K using a Micromeritics ASAP 2010 system. Magnetic properties of the samples were measured using a vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM) by varying the applied magnetic field from −20 to 20kOe. The Pd content in the prepared nanocatalyst was measured by inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES). An Agilent Cary 5000 UV–vis spectrophotometer was utilized for monitoring the progress of the catalytic reduction of 4-NP, 2-NA, RhB, MB, and MO. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation and characterization of the materials In this study, the MnO2 mesoporous microspheres with multiple cores were successfully fabricated. The preparation procedures are described in Scheme 1 . First, the SiO2 NPs were prepared by using the proven Stöber's method. Second, ferrocene was employed as the source for the magnetic Fe3O4 and carbon, through the solvothermal method; we successfully obtained the SiO2@Fe3O4@C spheres with carbon layers as the outer shell that completely covered the Fe3O4 layer. Third, the obtained SiO2@Fe3O4@C spheres were then reacted with the strong oxidizing KMnO4 under hydrothermal conditions, the carbon layers were thoroughly oxidized and etched by KMnO4, thus converting them into CO2. Simultaneously, KMnO4 was reduced to MnO2, which completely covered the SiO2@Fe3O4. Finally forming the SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2, which was used to fabricate Pd-based nanocatalyst (Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2). The morphologies of the prepared materials were investigated in detail by SEM and TEM. Fig. 1 a clearly shows that the SiO2 NPs have a uniform spherical morphology with an average diameter of 150nm. These SiO2 NPs do not almost aggregate in organic or aqueous solution. Then, in acetone solution, under hydrothermal and oxidation conditions, ferrocene was decomposed to Fe3O4 that covered the surface of the SiO2 NPs and the decomposed carbon was transferred to carbon layers that completely covered the SiO2@Fe3O4, thus forming the SiO2@Fe3O4@C spheres. Fig. 1b shows that the SiO2@Fe3O4@C spheres also have uniform spherical morphology with an average diameter of about 200nm. Fig. 1c provides the clearer structure of the SiO2@Fe3O4@C spheres, with the Fe3O4 layer of about 10nm in thickness, and the thickness of the outer carbon shell is about 20nm. Furthermore, Fig. 1c also reveals that Fe3O4 NPs with the diameter approximately 6nm. In our current study, we also investigated the effect of the dosage of ferrocene on the morphology of the SiO2@Fe3O4@C. The results indicated that under a low ferrocene dosage, the Fe3O4 layer and the outer carbon shell could not be formed. There was just agglomerated Fe3O4 and carbon NPs attached onto the surface of the SiO2 NPs (Fig. S1). When reacted with the strong oxidizing KMnO4, the outer carbon shell of the SiO2@Fe3O4@C spheres was completely oxidized to CO2 and MnO4 − was transformed into MnO2, which existed as thin nanosheets tightly packed on the Fe3O4 layer as shown in Fig. 1d. Clearly, mesoporous space is present between the crimped MnO2 nanosheets, thus the MnO2 layer can be defined as mesoporous MnO2 layer. Fig. 1d illustrates that the mesoporous MnO2 layer has a thickness of about 40nm. Fig. 1e shows the Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst, with Pd NPs attached on the MnO2 nanosheets compared to the unsupported SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 system. The Pd NPs have an average diameter of about 5nm. To further study the structure and composition of the obtained Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst, high angle annular dark field-scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) was conducted (Fig. 1f). Clearly, the Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst has Fe3O4 layer (Fe-K) on the SiO2 NPs, and mesoporous MnO2 (Mn-K) as the outer layer. Moreover, Pd NPs were highly dispersed on the outer mesoporous MnO2 layer (Pd-K and Pd-L). PXRD was used to analyze the phase structures of the SiO2@Fe3O4@C, SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2, and Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 (Fig. 2 a). The PXRD spectrum of SiO2@Fe3O4@C clearly exhibits the characteristic diffraction peaks of Fe3O4 at 2θ=30.1, 35.6, 43.8, 57.4, and 62.8°, corresponding to (220), (311), (400), (511), and (440) of Fe3O4 NPs, respectively [49]. When reacted with KMnO4 to fabricate SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2, additional diffraction peaks corresponding to MnO2 such as (120), (131), (300), (160), and (003) could also be identified. When modified by Pd NPs, the characteristic diffraction peaks for Pd NPs at 2θ=39.8 and 45.8° attributed to Pd(111) and Pd(200), respectively, were clearly observed, except for the diffraction peaks corresponding to the support [50]. The XRD analysis clearly demonstrates that Pd NPs are successfully anchored on the catalyst support. Furthermore, the EDS spectrum shown in Fig. 2b exhibits the composition of the Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst; revealing the existence of mainly O, Mn, Si, Pd, and Fe. Fig. 3 a shows the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 support and Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst. Noteworthy, both the prepared samples exhibit similar IV-type curves, and steep increase of N2 adsorption at high pressure (P/P0 >0.6) can be observed from the loops, indicating the mesoporous structure of SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 and Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2, mainly due to the mesoporous MnO2 layer. The pore size distributions of the two samples are shown in Fig. 3b. The SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 support exhibits a broad pore size distribution. However, Pd NPs-modified SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 exhibits a slight decrease in the pore size distribution, probably attributed to the grafting of the Pd NPs in the mesoporous structure. Moreover, the textual parameters of the prepared materials are listed in Table 1 . The SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 support has the surface area of 194.5m2 g−1, pore volume of 0.39m3 g−1, and average pore size of 9.2nm; however, when supported by Pd NPs, these parameters decrease to 171.5m2 g−1, 0.3m3 g−1, and 6.8nm, respectively. Further, the XPS was used to investigate the composition and metallic nature of the active Pd NPs in Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst. The wide survey scan spectrum of the obtained nanocatalyst is shown in Fig. 4 a, clearly revealing the existence of O, Mn, Fe, Si, and Pd elements in the catalyst, thus confirming the composition of the Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst. Using the C 1s peak position at 284.6eV as the reference, the Pd 3d spectrum shown in Fig. 4b exhibits double peaks corresponding to Pd3d5/2 (334.9eV) and Pd3d3/2 (340.2eV) attributed to Pd(0) species. The magnetic properties of the SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 support and the Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst were measured at room temperature. Fig. 5 shows the magnetization curves, indicating that the SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 support exhibits saturation magnetization of ca. 12emug−1. However, the Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst shows the saturation magnetization of about 8emug−1. Although the saturation magnetization value is not very high, it is sufficient for the immediate recycling of the Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst by using an external magnet. Fig. 5 inset shows the separation procedure for the Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst. Thus, separation and reuse of the noble metal based Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst is significantly important, which allows for the cost-effectiveness of the process. 3.2 HDC of 2,4-DCP Herein, the obtained Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst with a 6% Pd content (detected by the ICP-AES) was used as an effective catalyst for the catalytic HDC of 2,4-DCP under ambient conditions. Table 2 lists the results corresponding to the optimization of the reaction conditions. Entries 1–5 clearly show that NaOH is the optimized base in the HDC reaction. Under this basic condition, the HDC conversion of 2,4-DCP could reach upto 99.2% and the phenol selectivity was 99.8% in 300min. When the Pd content of Pd/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 was reduced to 4 and 2% (detected by the ICP-AES), longer reaction times, 360 and 480min, respectively, were required to obtain a HDC conversion over 95%. In this work, we also investigated the Pd/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 catalyst with Pd loading of 8% and 10%, and the HDC of 2,4-DCP almost can be completed in 260 and 240min, respectively. However, as is well known that Pd is a precious metal with high price, with higher Pd loading, the price of the catalysts should be much more expensive. Thus, here we chose the Pd/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst with a 6% Pd content as the optimal catalyst for the HDC reaction. Under higher reaction temperatures, such as 40 and 60°C, although the HDC reaction could reach a 99% conversion in 200 and 180min, respectively, we considered that the room temperature HDC should be energy saving. Therefore, the optimal reaction conditions for the HDC of 2,4-DCP in this study were set as follows: Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst with 6% Pd content, room temperature, NaOH as base, and 300min reaction time. The mechanistic pathway for the HDC of 2,4-DCP under the optimized reaction conditions was systematically investigated. Fig. 6 a reveals that the HDC of 2,4-DCP should proceed via following three pathways: First and second pathways involve the initial dechlorination of para-Cl or ortho-Cl, followed by the replacement by the active hydrogen to form 2-CP or 4-CP, which further results in HDC to phenol; the third pathway involves the simultaneous dechlorination of ortho-Cl and para-Cl generating phenol. Fig. 6b demonstrates that, during the progress of the HDC reaction, the relative concentration of 2,4-DCP gradually decreases and the relative concentration of phenol gradually increases. Here, the relative concentration is calculated from the concentration of the reactant or product during the reaction process that divided by the original concentration of the reactant 2,4-DCP. 2-CP was found in the reaction system as the only intermediate product [18,51,52]. 4-CP was not detected in the reaction process probably due to the steric hindrance effect, which resulted in substantial suppression of the hydrogenation of ortho-Cl in comparison to para-Cl [53]. When the intermediate 2-CP reached a certain concentration, its concentration also decreased gradually and finally it was transformed into phenol. The HDC of 2,4-DCP could be completed in 300min, and the highly toxic 2,4-DCP was completely converted into a less toxic and much useful product phenol. Further hydrogenation product cyclohexanone was not detected in the reaction process; this was mainly attributed to the low dosage of the nanocatalyst as reported in previous study [54,55]. The HDC reaction mechanism can be explained as follows: First, H2 that dissolved in the reaction mixture was adsorbed on the surface of the Pd NPs, which resulted in the formation of the active hydrogen atoms. Second, the active hydrogen atoms attacked the CCl bond of the 2,4-DCP to form phenol and HCl. Finally, the HCl reacted rapidly with NaOH to form NaCl that dissolved in water, thus preventing the accumulation of HCl on the surface of the catalyst [56]. As the obtained Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst exhibited excellent magnetic property, its reusability was also investigated by a magnetic recycle process. Herein, 10mg of Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst was recovered by using an external magnet in the batch reaction and washed three times with H2O and ethanol, respectively, then the nanocatalyst was reused in the subsequent catalytic runs. Fig. 6c shows a slight decrease in the HDC conversion of 2,4-DCP after six catalytic runs. However, the conversion was still above 90%, and the phenol selectivity was just above 80%. This was attributed to the formation of the HDC byproduct NaCl that covered the surface of the Pd NPs, leading to partial poisoning of the active sites; and moreover, in the recycle process, the Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst was also slightly lost. Moreover, the general applicability of the Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst in the HDC of other CPs was also investigated, and the corresponding results are listed in Table 3 . The CPs, including 2-CP, 3-CP, and 4-CP have near 100% conversion and selectivity toward phenol in 60min (Fig. S2a), indicating that one chlorine-substituted CPs was much easier to be dechlorinated. However, the HDC of 2,4,6-TCP was not easy; when the catalyst dosage was increased to 20mg, in 300min, the conversion of 2,4,6-TCP was 98.5%, and the selectivity toward phenol was 88% (Fig. S2b). However, when the reaction time was extended to 500min, 2,4,6-TCP could be completely converted to phenol. Therefore, the Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst exhibited excellent activity for the HDC of highly toxic CPs under ambient conditions. 3.3 Catalytic reduction of nitroaromatic compounds (4-NP and 2-NA) and organic dyes (RhB, MB, and MO) The obtained Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst was also tested for catalytic reduction of nitroaromatic compounds such as 4-NP, 2-NA and other few substituted nitroaromatic in order to broaden the application of substrate breadth (Table S1). 4-NP has a light yellow color with absorption peak at 317nm. When fresh aqueous solution of NaBH4 was added, the light yellow color solution changed to bright yellow and the absorption peak shifted to 400nm (Fig. S3) [57]. 4-NP was transformed into 4-nitrophenolate ions. 4-NP and NaBH4 mixture maintained the absorption strength at 400nm and its solution color for a long time without the addition of Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst, indicating that the reduction reaction could not occur only in the presence of reductant NaBH4. However, when Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst was added, the catalytic reduction of 4-NP to 4-AP immediately began. The bright yellow color reaction mixture gradually changed to colorless, along with the gradual decrease in the absorption peak intensity at 400nm. Moreover, a new absorption peak appeared and enhanced gradually at 300nm, indicating the formation of the reduction product 4-AP. The reduction reaction could be completed in 324s (Fig. 7 a). On the other hand, 2-NA exhibits a strong absorption peak at 412nm. When only NaBH4 was introduced into the 2-NA aqueous solution, its yellow color and the absorption strength at 412nm remained the same for a long time similar to 4-NP. However, on addition of the Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst into 2-NA and NaBH4 mixture solution, the absorbance at 412nm first decreased and then completely disappeared in 200s (Fig. 7b). In the current study, amount of the Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst used in the catalytic reduction reactions was very small, and NaBH4 was used in excess compared to 4-NP and 2-NA; therefore, the reactions could be regarded as pseudo-first order reactions. Thus, the following equation could be used to determine the rate of the reactions: (1) ln ( A t A 0 ) = ln ( C t C 0 ) = − Kt where K represents the rate constant, and C0 and Ct are the initial and final concentrations of 4-NP or 2-NA at times 0 and t, respectively. The linear relation between the ln(Ct/C0) vs reaction time also indicated the pseudo-first order reaction kinetics of the catalytic reduction reactions. The reaction constant value K determined from the slopes of the straight lines was found to be 0.015 and 0.023s−1, respectively, for the catalytic reduction of 4-NP and 2-NA (Fig. 7c). Except for the investigation of the above mentioned CPs and nitrocompounds, the organic dyes, highly toxic organic compounds that exist in chemical wastewater, were also investigated. Thus, the Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst fabricated in this study was also employed in the catalytic disposal of the organic dyes RhB, MB, and MO. Fig. 8 a–c shows that RhB, MB, and MO have strong absorption peaks at 554, 663, and 465nm, respectively. Addition of just NaBH4 into RhB, MB, and MO did not lead to their reduction. However, when the Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst was introduced into the organic dyes and NaBH4 mixture, the absorption peak intensity gradually decreased as indicated by the UV–vis spectra (Fig. 8a–c), and finally the pink colored RhB solution, blue colored MB solution, and orange colored MO solution became colorless, indicating the reduction of RhB, MB, and MO. The linear relation between the ln(Ct/C0) vs reaction time displayed in Fig. 8d–f also reveals that catalytic reduction of RhB, MB, and MO follows the pseudo-first order reaction. The values of the reaction constant K were determined to be 0.0063, 0.031, and 0.0087s−1, respectively, for the catalytic reduction of RhB, MB, and MO. RhB, MB, and MO dyes have a CN or NN functional group, and the reduction reactions were considered to be completed when the CN or NN was hydrogenated (Fig. 8 g–i). The reaction mechanism for the catalytic reduction of nitroaromatic compounds 4-NP, 2-NA, and organic dyes RhB, MB, and MO involves following three steps: First, the reductant BH4 − in the reaction mixture was adsorbed on the Pd NPs, and a hydride was transferred to the Pd NPs surface to form the Pd−H bonds; Second, the nitrocompounds (4-NP and 2-NA) or the organic dye molecules (MB, MO, and RhB) were absorbed onto the surfaces of the Pd NPs, and active H atoms on the surface of the Pd NPs tended to be captured by nitro-group or the unsaturated bond group, respectively. Finally, the nitro-group or the unsaturated bond group was hydrogenated and the reduction products were desorbed from the Pd NPs, which resulted in reactivation of the Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst [8,58–61]. The catalytic activity of the prepared Pd/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst in the catalytic reduction reactions was also compared to those of other reported NMNPs based catalysts, and the results are listed in Table 4 . Clearly, the Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst exhibits higher catalytic activity in the catalytic reduction of nitrocompounds and comparable catalytic activity in the catalytic reduction organic dyes compared with other NMNPs based catalysts [9,62–69]. This may be attributed to the mesoporous structure of the MnO2 shell and the highly dispersed Pd NPs that enhance the easy accessibility of the active sites and the mass transfer effect, thus subsequently enhancing the catalytic activity of the Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst. For the noble metal based catalysts, their easy recovery and reusability are very necessary. Herein the superparamagnetic Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst can be easily recovered after the catalytic reduction of nitro compounds (Fig. 7a and b inset) and organic dyes (Fig. 8g–i) by using an external magnet. The catalytic reduction of 4-NP and MB as the probe reactions indicated that, the Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst could be reused for at least six times, without significant decrease in the catalytic activity (Fig. 9 ). The catalyst reused for six times was collected and characterized by TEM, and the results showed that the morphology of the Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst was well maintained (Fig. S4). And the Pd content only slightly decreased to 5.92% after six runs. The above mentioned results indicated the reusability and stability of the Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst. 4 Conclusions In this study, SiO2 NPs were used as the core and ferrocene and KMnO4 as precursors. Thus SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 microspheres with magnetic SiO2@Fe3O4 core and mesoporous MnO2 shell were successfully fabricated as a novel magnetic catalyst support. Then the Pd NPs were anchored on the mesoporous MnO2 shell with high dispersion. The obtained Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst was empolyed in the environmental catalysis for the HDC of highly toxic CPs and catalytic reduction of the widely used nitroaromatics and organic dyes, and showing excellent catalytic activities as well as easy reusability and stability. coredata.dc:description: In this study, magnetic SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 microspheres with uniform morphology and mesoporous MnO2 shell were successfully prepared. The MnO2 sheets structured mesoporous shell could provide a large specific surface area, thereby increasing the catalytically active sites. Thus, magnetic SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 microspheres were used as a catalyst support. Palladium nanoparticles (Pd NPs) were successfully anchored with high dispersion on SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 surface, successfully obtained Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst with a Pd weight percentage of 6%. The obtained nanocatalyst was employed in the hydrodechlorination of highly toxic 2,4-dichlorophenol and catalytic reduction of the widely used nitroaromatics and organic dyes under ambient conditions. In these catalytic reactions, the Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst with large and accessible pore surface area exhibited excellent catalytic activity as compared to other noble metal supported catalysts. The Pd(6%)/SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 nanocatalyst could also be easily and conveniently recovered from the reaction mixture by using an external magnet, attributed to its magnetism, thus preventing the catalyst loss. Moreover, it could also be reused for at least six times without significant decrease in the catalytic activity, indicating its excellent reusability and stability. This study provides a useful platform and a new perspective for fabricating mesoporous MnO2 microspheres based noble metals modified catalysts for environmental catalysis.
coredata.dc:title: Palladium nanoparticles supported on SiO2@Fe3O4@m-MnO2 mesoporous microspheres as a highly efficient and recyclable catalyst for hydrodechlorination of 2,4-dichlorophenol and reduction of nitroaromatic compounds and organic dyes
